SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Class Quoter

java.lang.Object
org.klojang.jdbc.Quoter
public final class Quoter extends Object

Escapes and quotes values according to the quoting rules of the target database. You do not normally need to concern yourself with quoting and escaping unless you want to embed a SQL expression in the SQL to be executed. For example, suppose (pretty unrealistically) you have a variable firstName in your program, and you want to embed the following expression in your SQL: "SUBSTRING('" + firstName + "', 1, 3)". If the value of firstName comes from outside your program, you expose yourself to the risk of SQL injection. In this case you should use a Quoter to eliminate the risk: "SUBSTRING(" + quoter.quoteValue(firstName) + ", 1, 3)". For SQL function calls in particular, you can also use Quoter.sqlFunction(): quoter.sqlFunction("SUBSTRING", firstName, 1, 3).

Only use a Quoter to escape and quote strings within the SQL expression. In any other case escaping and quoting is taken care of by Klojang JDBC.

See Also:
  • SQLExpression
  • BeanValueProcessor.process(Object, String, Object, Quoter)
  • SQLSession.quoteValue(Object)

  • Method Details

    • quoteValue

      public String quoteValue(Object value)

      Returns a properly escaped and quoted string. More precisely:

      • If the value is null, the literal string "NULL" (without the quotes) is returned.
      • If the value is a Number, a Boolean, or a SQLExpression, the value is returned as-is. That is, toString() will be called on the value, but the resulting string will not be quoted.
      • Otherwise toString() is called on the value, and the resulting string is escaped and quoted according to the quoting rules of the target database.
      Parameters:
      value - the value to quote
      Returns:
      a properly escaped and quoted string
      See Also:
      • Statement.enquoteLiteral(String)

    • quoteIdentifier

      public String quoteIdentifier(String identifier)
      If necessary, quotes the specified identifier (e.g. a column name or table name) according to the quoting rules of the target database. Use this method if the identifier is passed in from outside your program to prevent SQL injection.
      Parameters:
      identifier - the identifier to quote
      Returns:
      the quoted identifier
      See Also:
      • Statement.enquoteIdentifier(String, boolean)

    • sqlFunction

      public SQLExpression sqlFunction(String name, Object... args)
      Generates a SQL function call in which each of the function arguments is escaped and quoted using the quoteValue() method.
      Parameters:
      name - the name of the function, like "SUBSTRING" or "CONCAT". Note that the function name is itself not escaped or quoted. Therefore, with SQL injection in mind, be wary of this being a dynamically generated value.
      args - the function arguments. Each of the provided arguments will pass through quoteValue(Object).
      Returns:
      a SQLExpression representing a SQL function call
